title: For all he’s done, Mike Tirico will experience ‘thrill of a lifetime’ calling first Super Bowl for NBC
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Mike Tirico will call his first Super Bowl for NBC, marking a major milestone in his broadcasting career.
Tirico will lead the broadcast alongside Cris Collinsworth for Super Bowl LX featuring the Patriots and Seahawks.
After the Super Bowl, Tirico will host NBC's Olympic studio program, reflecting his extensive involvement in sports coverage.

title: 60 fun facts, stats, and things to know about Super Bowl LX before Patriots take on Seahawks
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Patriots, with second-year quarterback Drake Maye, are underdogs against the Seahawks in Super Bowl LX at Levi's Stadium.
The game marks the 11th Super Bowl rematch and Seattle's fourth appearance, all within the past 21 years.
Patriots' turnaround could be historical, winning after a 4-win season; Seahawks boast top scoring defense and strong DVOA.

title: Patriots’ Mike Vrabel reportedly received pointers from Bill Belichick and a rival coach ahead of Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots coach Mike Vrabel sought advice from Bill Belichick and Chiefs' Andy Reid before Super Bowl LX against the Seahawks.
Vrabel also relied on offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels for preparation guidance; McDaniels heads into his 10th Super Bowl.
Vrabel, in his first coaching year, led the Patriots to 14 wins and won Coach of the Year before Super Bowl LX.

title: 5 things at stake during the Patriots’ Super Bowl rematch with the Seahawks
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots aim for a record seventh Super Bowl win against the Seahawks, surpassing the Steelers' current record.
Coach Mike Vrabel could become the first to win a Super Bowl with the Patriots as both player and coach.
Quarterback Drake Maye seeks to become the first second-year QB to win the Super Bowl since Russell Wilson in 2014.

title: Stefon Diggs hopes Super Bowl LX can strengthen Hall of Fame case. Would a win put Patriots’ WR in Canton?
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Stefon Diggs hopes a Super Bowl LX win will bolster his Hall of Fame chances with the New England Patriots.
Diggs recognizes his career accolades are strong but not guaranteed for Hall of Fame induction, despite a strong season.
Diggs ranks 38th in receiving yards and 43rd in touchdowns, with potential to climb if he continues performing well.

title: Would the Patriots’ dynasty have ever happened without new Hall of Famer Adam Vinatieri?
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Adam Vinatieri, former Patriots and Colts kicker, was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2026.
Vinatieri played 24 NFL seasons, scoring a record 2,673 points, including 21 seasons with over 100 points.
Known for clutch performances, he secured Patriots' victories in two Super Bowls with late-game-winning field goals.

title: Mike Vrabel throws a wrinkle in Patriots’ final practice ahead of Super Bowl LX
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Mike Vrabel simulated a longer halftime break during the Patriots' final practice for Super Bowl LX.
The practice included typical routines, but also focused on recovering injured players like Harold Landry III and Robert Spillane.
Drake Maye participated fully despite a shoulder concern, while Hunter Henry and Efton Chism III were last to leave the field.

title: Patriots-Seahawks Super Bowl will likely come down to which quarterback makes the fewest mistakes
author: Chad Finn
bullets: The Patriots and Seahawks face off in Super Bowl LX with quarterbacks Drake Maye and Sam Darnold in focus.
Both Maye and Darnold are former No. 3 overall picks and key to their team's Super Bowl success.
Milton Williams and Jaxon Smith-Njigba are notable players to watch, impacting critical defensive and offensive plays.

title: Mass. company pleads guilty to OSHA violation that led to employee’s death
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: John Oliveira & Sons Stamp Concrete, Inc. pleaded guilty to willful OSHA violations in a worker's 2023 death.
The company admitted no safety device was in place when a 1,500-pound conveyor crushed Josué Tiquiram.
Sentencing on May 4, the company faces up to five years probation and a $500,000 fine.

title: Here’s what Healey put up in her Super Bowl bet with Washington state governor
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Massachusetts Governor Maura Healey bet Seattle Governor Bob Ferguson New England's iconic chowder and Dunkin' if Patriots lose Super Bowl LX.
Washington Governor Bob Ferguson promised to send Seattle's best shellfish and coffee to Healey if Seahawks lose Super Bowl LX.
Healey declared this weekend New England Patriots Appreciation Weekend and will attend Super Bowl LX during a work trip to California.
